image.altText: A red stage with Qantas logo on projector

items.synopsis: Qantas is holding its AGM, just a few days after the airline defended itself against so-called "ghost flight" allegations. Follow proceedings as they happen with our live blog.

title.children: Qantas board on notice after 83pc protest vote by shareholders over executive pay

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has followed Wall Street's bounce to close higher on Friday, up 1.1% to 6,978 points. All sectors — minus energy — finished higher for the day, with industrials leading the charge, up 7.4%. Real estate (+2.1%), academic and educational services (+2%), healthcare (+1.6%), consumer cyclicals (+1.4%) and financials (+1.3%) recorded the biggest gains. More modest gains were recorded for technology stocks (+0.8%), basic materials (+0.7%), consumer non-cyclicals (+0.3%) and utilities (+0.3%). Energy was the only sector in the red, falling by a 0.1%. Block was far and away the best performer, after Afterpay's parent company lifted its earnings projections, while Treasury Wine tumbled after a round of discounted capital raising to fund its acquisition of DAOU Vineyards in California. The top performers for the day: Block +25.2% Weebit Nano +12.1% Sayona Mining +9% Neuren Pharmaceuticals +8.5% Core Lithium +8.5% At the other end, the worst performers were: Treasury Wine -7.8% Gold Road Resources -2.4% Bellevue Gold -2.2% Whitehaven Coal -1.9% Paladin Energy -1.5%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX finishes on a positive note as Block shares surge, Treasury Wine tanks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A change in leadership at Qantas and the ACCC has led to more of the same from both, which is a looming disaster for the airline and a credit to the regulator. Where Vanessa Hudson is rapidly burning through whatever goodwill was gifted to her when she accepted the poison chalice that is the stewardship of Qantas, ACCC boss Gina Cass-Gottlieb is slowly building her reputation as one of the nation's most effective regulators. For whatever reason, Hudson opted to detonate that sliver of goodwill during the past week by lodging a flimsy, highly technical defence against the ACCC's legal action alleging the airline sold thousands of tickets to unsuspecting customers on flights that already had been cancelled. And, as anyone who has ever tried can attest, attempting to retrieve money from the Flying Kangaroo is no easy task. You can read business editor Ian Verrender's analysis of the airline's turbulent end to a rough week below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANALYSIS: A shareholder revolt may be the least of the new Qantas boss's worries

featuredLink.title: A shareholder revolt may be the least of new Qantas boss Hudson's worries as the ACCC goes in for the kill

children.content: A change in leadership at Qantas and the ACCC has led to more of the same from both, which is a looming disaster for the airline

Where Vanessa Hudson is rapidly burning through whatever goodwill was gifted to her when she accepted the poison chalice that is the stewardship of Qantas, ACCC boss Gina Cass-Gottlieb is slowly building her reputation as one of the nation's most effective regulators.

For whatever reason, Hudson opted to detonate that sliver of goodwill during the past week by lodging a flimsy, highly technical defence against the ACCC's legal action alleging the airline sold thousands of tickets to unsuspecting customers on flights that already had been cancelled.
And, as anyone who has ever tried can attest, attempting to retrieve money from the Flying Kangaroo is no easy task.
analysis of the airline's turbulent end to a rough week below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With the RBA's cash rate meeting fast approaching next Tuesday, markets are growing more and more convinced that we'll see them deliver a rate hike. It would be the first time the RBA would increase the cash rate since in four months, and all of the big four banks are expecting a 0.25 percentage point increase, which would take the cash rate to 4.35% — the highest rate since November 2011. Scott Solomon, a co-portfolio manager at T. Rowe Price says it's not necessarily an obvious decision that the RBA would lift rates, given the messaging by other central banks around the world. " The decision is not an obvious one as most other central banks around the world have indicated they are likely done hiking," he said. "However, given a recent strong inflation print, the minutes of the prior meeting showing a surprising balance between a hike and a no hike decision. In addition, the recent easing of financial conditions post the Fed's dovish pause, the calculus is tipped in favour of a hike. " But Mr Solomon says the RBA could surprise us with a smaller hike of 0.15 percentage points — although he conceded it was "unlikely" to happen. "Governor Bullock will likely try to pitch the decision as largely precautionary in nature," he said. "In fact, I think it would be a nice opportunity to hike 15 [basis points] and bring the terminal rate to a more traditional 4.25%. " It is unlikely they do that – but the RBA is no stranger to surprises and would check a lot of boxes." All will be revealed next Tuesday at 2:30pm AEDT.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could the RBA deliver a rate hike surprise with a 0.15 percentage point increase next week?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Thailand is in touch with Iran and other governments that can make contact with Hamas, seeking the safe release of nearly two dozen Thai nationals being held hostage by the organisation, according to its foreign minister. Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara said Iran, which is close to Hamas, had promised to help with negotiations. At least 23 Thai nationals were among more than 240 people taken hostage when Hamas attacked Israel on October 7. Some 30,000 Thai nationals were working in Israel at the time of the attack. More than 7,000 have since returned home on government evacuation flights. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Thailand in talks with Iran and others for Hamas hostages release

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel will return Gazans working inside the country to the besieged Palestinian territory, the government says. "Israel is severing all contact with Gaza. There will be no more Palestinian workers from Gaza," the Israeli security cabinet announced in a statement late Thursday. "Those workers from Gaza who were in Israel on the day of the outbreak of the war will be returned to Gaza," it added, without specifying how many people would be sent back. Before the start of the war, Israel had issued work permits to some 18,500 Gazans, according to COGAT, the Israeli defence body responsible for Palestinian civilian affairs. COGAT did not immediately return a request for information on the number of Gazans working inside Israel at the time of the attack on October 7. Reporting with AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it will return Gazan labourers to the enclave and sever 'all contact'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two more Australians trapped in Gaza have been able to flee the enclave during the latest opening of the border crossing into Egypt, AAP reports citing a Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson. One citizen and one permanent resident were able to exit through the Rafah crossing out of Gaza during the second window for foreign nationals to evacuate on Thursday. The Australians, who were on a list to get out of Gaza in the first opportunity on Wednesday, made the crossing into Egypt with the help of consular officials from the UK. They will join the rest of the other 23 Australians who got out of Gaza safely on Wednesday for onward travel to Cairo. "We continue to engage closely with partners in the region and do all we can to enable the remaining Australians in Gaza, who wish to leave, to do so as soon as possible," a foreign affairs department spokesman said. "The timing of those departures depends on a range of factors. "The situation in Gaza continues to be highly challenging and can change rapidly." More than 800 people have been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing under a deal brokered between the US, Egypt, Israel and Qatar. A third crossing opportunity is expected to take place on Friday. Reporting with AAP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two more Australians leave Gaza
